occurrences.line_text: Thereof by force to take their beastly pleasure.
That monstrous Beast by finall force to quell,
By force, he gan his hundred tongues apply,
At last when as he found his force to shrincke,
To stay the steppe, ere forced to retrate.
From turning backe, and forced her to stay:
Shooke him so hard, that forced him to speake.
That forced him to stoupe vpon his knee;
With forced fury following his behest,
From him, that would haue forced me to dye?
The whiles on foot was forced for to yeed,
That from his saddle forced him to fly:
That forced him his ground to trauerse wide,
With foule repulse from Fraunce was forced to retire.
Who her would forced haue to haue forlore
Her fayned Paramour, her forced guest,
That forced him his shield to disaduaunce:
That with the force it backward forced him to bow.
He forced was to strike, and saue him selfe from teene.
That forced them from fighting to refraine,
That forced him to leaue his loftie sell,
That forced them to seeke some couert bowre,
That she him forced backward to retreat,
Till that vneath they forced were for lacke
That she them forced hand to ioyne in hand,
And forced him, maulgre, it vp to reare.
That he was forced to withdraw aside;
And forced it, the honour that is dew
That the bold Prince was forced foote to giue
And forced him to throw it quite away,
And forced them, how euer strong and stout
And forced to forgoe th'attempt remedilesse.
And forced me to so infamous deed,
And in his tender armes her forced vp to stay.
He forced was to turne from him and fly:
Was forced there to leaue them both behynd,
In winters wrathfull time, he forced him to flie.
With doubled forces high aboue the ground:
His forces faile, ne can no longer fight.
That daunted with their forces hideous,
And sluggish german doest thy forces slake,
Eftsoones his manly forces gan to faile,
In that bright shield, and all their forces spend
Till prickt with courage, and thy forces pryde,
Knit all his forces, and gan soone vnbrace
Oft he re'nforst, and oft his forces fayld,
They gaue fresh charge, their forces gan to faile,
To ioyne your force, their forces to repell,
Hauing his forces all in one accrewed,
But now their forces greatly were decayd,
And far aboue thy forces pitch to sore.
And all thy forces gather vnto thee;
He all his forces streight to him did reare,
Their forces furie, and their terror slake;
Where singled forces faile, conioynd may gaine.
Their wounds recur'd, and forces reincreast,
Forceth it swell aboue his wonted mood,
And of so fierce and forcible despight,
The stone-dead quarrey fals so forciblie,
Into the Castle entred forcibly,
And with strong flight did forcibly diuide
Yielded by him, that held it forcibly.
That the sharpe steele arriuing forcibly
And with his naked hands him forcibly assayld.
For loe that Guest would beare her forcibly,
Forcibly driuen with contrarie tydes
So thicke they fell, and forcibly were sent,
That forcibly to ground they both together went.
Yet was the stroke so forcibly applide,
So forcibly, that with his owne hands might
Is forcibly kept downe, till he be throughly queld.
Did him suppresse, and forcibly subdew;
Now forst to yield, now forcing to inuade,
Yet forcing it to faine, him forth thence led
Forcing to doe, that did him fowle misseeme:
Forcing in vaine the rest to her to tell,
But backe rebounding, left the forckhead keene;
And him to ferrie ouer that deepe ford:
Where drenched deepe he found in that dull ford
Where them awaited ready at the ford
With cruell threats, his passage through the ford to let.
And through the ford to passen did assay;
But labour'd long in that deepe ford with vaine disease.
Ne doe they need with water of the ford,
That doth thus strongly ward the Castle of the ford.
A fordonne wight from dore of death mote raise,
And many soules in dolours had fordonne:
That his frayle thighes nigh wearie and fordonne
That many errant knights hath foule fordonne:
Whose wofull parents she hath wickedly fordonne.
Least we vnweeting hap to be fordonne:
That thy sad people vtterly fordonne,
And the rich furrowes flote, all quite fordonne:
And squiers make hast to helpe their Lords fordonne.
For that he sau'd the victour from fordonne:
Where she had them both shamefully fordonne,
Which lawlesse men had formerly fordonne.
And many errant Knights hath there fordonne;
Whereas so many knights had fouly bene fordonne.
In the next brooke, by who[m] that feend shold be fordonne.
But he, whose hart through feare was late fordonne,
Great Gloriane, that Tyrant to fordoo,
That was fore by the way, she did him bring,
Foreby a fountaine, where I late him left
To rest him selfe, foreby a fountaine side,
Foreby that idle strond, of him were told,
Foreby a riuer in a pleasaunt dale,
Foreby the Riuer, that whylome was hight
A goodly Ladie did foreby them rush,
Foreby a narrow foord, to them well knowne,
Flowne at a flush of Ducks, foreby the brooke,
We chaunst to come foreby a couert glade
Yet wilfull man he neuer would forecast,
For feare of mischiefe, which she did forecast
Bold Britomart, as she had late forecast,
Forecasting, how his foe he might annoy,
All desperate of his fore-damned spright,
To aide a virgin desolate foredonne.
Both sire, and friends, and all for euer to forego.
But could not stay; so fast she did foregoe,
And things foregone through many ages held,
A girlond for her dainty forehead fit,
His sweatie forehead in the breathing wind,
Vpon her yuory forehead that same day
Knit with a golden bauldricke, which forelay
As if that life to losse they had forelent,
Forelifting vp aloft his speckled brest,
For thy the first did in the forepart sit,
With ragged monuments of times forepast,
To drincke hereof, whereby all cares forepast
And taking vsurie of time forepast,
And all forepast displeasures to repeale.
The first of them could things to come foresee:
Trembling with horrour, as that did foresee
That had he not foreseene with heedfull vew,
Out of the foreside of their forgerie,
For whither he through fatall deepe foresight
He had a sharpe foresight, and working wit,
The fatall purpose of diuine foresight,
Who through foresight of his eternall skill,
The rugged forhead that with graue foresight
The royall child with readie quicke foresight,
Which did not them preuent with vigilant foresight.
Till that by fortune, passing all foresight,
Is not enough thy euill life forespent?
Walkt in that forest, whom he had not taught
Raunging the forest wide on courser free,
At last as chaunst them by a forest side
With greedy pace forth rushing from the forest nye.
Thicke forest, was bescratcht, & both his feet nigh lame.
Fast flying through this forest from her fo,
That through this forest wandreth thus alone;
And with him forth into the forest went,
Out of that forest should escape their might;
Into that forest farre they thence him led,
Both through a forest ryding did deuise
Him selfe out of the forest he did wynd,
Yet death then, would the like mishaps forestall,
And eke of honour she did him forestall.
But euermore, those Damzels did forestall
That she therefore would him ere long forestall.
Abandon this forestalled place at erst,
That all the woodes and forestes did resownd;
Downe in a dale, hard by a forests side,
Sith that in saluage forests she did dwell,
Did spend her dayes, and lov'd in forests wyld to space.
Through hils, through dales, throgh forests, & throgh plaines
The sacred things, and holy heasts foretaught.
And with the sight amazd, forgat his furious forse.
That how the time was fled, they quite forgate,
The Prince soone hearkned, and his life forgaue.
Yet all was forg'd and spred with golden foyle,
And fittest for to forge true-seeming lyes;
As from a forge out of their burning shields,
In smithes fire-spitting forge, and nayles like clawes appeard.
As in the smoky forge it was compilde,
So could she forge all colours, saue the trew.
Framed in goldsmithes forge with cunning hand:
That she could forge in her malicious head,
For he so crafty was to forge and face,
Whose forged beauty he did take in hand,
By forged treason, or by open fight
Her deedes were forged, and her words false coynd,
Who with her forged beautie did seduce
She seem'd to passe: so forged things do fairest shew.
With forged cause them falsely to defame;
So meaning to suppresse both forged guile,
And foule blaspheme that Queene for forged guyle,
Not with such forged showes, as fitter beene
Oft interlacing many a forged lie,
Of such malengine and fine forgerie,
Out of the foreside of their forgerie,
Fie on such forgerie (said Artegall)
That it indeed is nought but forgerie,
Will iudged be, and painted forgery,
But onely womanish fine forgery,
But now for feare her beads she did forget.
Whom great griefe made forget the raines to hold
Made him forget all that Fidelia told.
Whiles creeping slomber made him to forget
Yet will I not forgoe, ne yet forget
Where lying still a while, both did forget
Now made forget their former cruell mood,
Selfe to forget to mind another, is ouersight.
He would her shortly leaue, and former loue forget.
And mighty hands forget their manlinesse;
Forget his patience, and yeeld vengeaunce dew
My tedious trauell doe forget thereby;
Forgetfull of the hanging victory:
Forgetfull of the hungry rage, which late
Forgetfull of his owne, that mindes anothers cares.
Proud wemen, vaine, forgetfull of their yoke:
Forgetfull of his safety, hath his right way lost.
Forgetfull each to haue bene euer others frend.
Forgetfull of her owne, to minde his feares:
Forgets with warie ward them to awayt,
She yet forgets, that she of men was kynded:
In which forgetting warres, he onely ioyed
But mote thy goodlyhed forgiue it mee,
Nath'lesse to thee thy folly I forgiue,
That he mote algates dye, yet did his death forgiue.
But to forbeare doth not forgiue the det.
Which if ye please forgiue, I will therefore
But onely breath sith that I did forgiue.
And to great ones such follies doe forgiue,
That God to vs forgiueth euery howre
Forgo that royall maides bequeathed care,
I neither can my loue, ne yet my life forgo.
For she had vow'd, she sayd, not to forgo
With wounds, is ready to forgo the ghost:
Sith Vna now he algates must forgoe,
Yet will I not forgoe, ne yet forget
Then must he her forgoe with foule defame,
Some of sworne friends, that did their faith forgoe;
Ne her owne Amoret forgoe so light
Forgoe the purchase of my gotten pray,
For no intreatie would forgoe so glorious spoyle.
And forced to forgoe th'attempt remedilesse.
But loosing soone his shield, did it forgoe,
Then doe your selfe, for dread of shame, forgoe
Forst to forgoe his pray there in the place,
For he would not his greedie grype forgoe,
And continence of life, that all forgon,
And broke their speares; yet neither has forgon
That hath his sword through hard assay forgone,
The vse of armes, and battell quite forgone:
That for his sake his deare life had forgone;
She has forgot, how many a wofull stowre
The well of life, ne yet his vertues had forgot.
He nought forgot, how he whilome had sworne,
Whiles in the bush he lay, not yet forgot:
That shortly he forgot the ieopardie,
That hath so soone forgot the excellence
In balefull night, where all things are forgot;
And soone forgot his former sickly paine;
Who had forgot, that whilome I heard tell
That shortly she Malbecco has forgot,
Forgot he was a man, and Gealosie is hight.
There as he lay, his wound he soone forgot,
Which she forgot, whereby excuse to make:
A wofull wretched maid, of God and man forgot.
And all the raging seas for ioy forgot to rore.
Hath now forgot, where he was plast of yore,
But through great fury both their skill forgot,
They heare him not, they haue forgot his lore,
They quite forgot, and scornd all former law;
And of the wicked world forgotten quight,
Her iuorie forhead, full of bountie braue,
Abiecting, th'earth with his faire forhead strooke:
The rugged forhead that with graue foresight
About her eares, does beat her brest, & forhead knockes.
Their frowning forheads with rough hornes yclad,
Gay girlonds, from the Sun their forheads faire to shade.
Doubleth her haste for feare to be for-hent,
The tongues of Serpents with three forked stings,
That through his haberieon the forkehead flew,
That Ladies loue vnto his Lord forlent,
For ruth of gentle knight so fowle forlore:
And mortall life gan loath, as thing forlore,
Where all the Nymphes haue her vnwares forlore,
To saue my Lord, in wretched plight forlore;
When euer they their heauenly bowres forlore;
Of the Rich strond, their charets they forlore,
To him, and to all th'vnworthy world forlore
Who her would forced haue to haue forlore
Lightly she leaped, as a wight forlore,
In her fraile wit, that now her quite forlore:
But in that wildernesse, of men forlore,
With which that wretched Greeke, that life forlore
But go, which way they list, their guide they haue forlore.
Is mine owne loue, though me she haue forlore,
Whom when those knights so froward and forlore
To send her succour, being of all hope forlore.
Of his first quest, which he had long forlore;
The Willow worne of forlorne Paramours,
Who now is left to keepe the forlorne maid
When two of three her Nephews are so fowle forlorne?
The forlorne mayd did with loues longing burne,
Such now he marcheth to this man forlorne,
When all was past, tooke vp his forlorne weed,
The forlorne Maiden, whom your eyes haue seene
And ye the forlorne reliques of his powre,
Her late forlorne and naked he had found,
Belphoebe fowle forlorne.
Is all his force forlorne, and all his glory donne?
His forlorne steed from him the victour wan;
To them, that liu'd therein in state forlorne;
The bowels of wide Fraunce, a forlorne Dame,
Through discord, and the royall throne forlorne:
Late King, now captiue, late Lord, now forlorne,
And in a rocky caue as wight forlorne,
Now lyest thou a lumpe of earth forlorne,
Great pittie sure, that ye be so forlorne
At wilde aduenture, like a forlorne weft,
And he himselfe himselfe loath'd so forlorne,
So shamefully forlorne of womankind;
Be theirs, that haue so cruell thee forlorne;
Then came those sixe sad brethren, like forlorne,
Make meanes to win thy libertie forlorne,
They doe thy loue, forlorne in womens thraldome see.
And his faire limbs left in the woods forlorne;
Whilest still she stands as stonisht and forlorne:
Or fortune I my countrie haue forlorne,
And wretched life forlorne for vengement of his theft.
But as thou hast thy steed forlorne with shame,
In which this Lady languisheth forlorne,
And wend abrode, though feeble and forlorne,
Holding a staffe in hand for more formalitee.
The skilfull Palmer formally did frame.
And form'd so liuely in each perfect part
Of earthly mould, and form'd of flesh and bone,
And with foule vgly forme did her disgrace:
T'adorne thy forme according thy desart,
That houses forme within was rude and strong,
Then is mans body both for powre and forme,
That had from hoggish forme him brought to naturall.
Which when as forme and feature it does ketch,
Ne when the life decayes, and forme does fade,
But th'only forme and outward fashion;
Which that same witch had in this forme engraft,
Could frame in earth, and forme of substance base,
I doe not forme them to the common line
So did this Ladies goodly forme decay,
And changing all that forme of common weale,
To leaue his proper forme, and other shape to take.
And gan her forme and feature to expresse,
In perfect forme, as this good Lady felt,
In sort as they were formed aunciently;
For of the earth they formed were of yore;
At last dull wearinesse of former fight
The broken reliques of their former cruelty.
Dimmed her former beauties shining ray,
Time and suffised fates to former kynd
And on their former iourney forward pas,
And trembling yet through feare of former hate;
Till he recouered had his former hew:
Or wrapped be in loues of former Dame,
By triall of his former harmes and cares,
And so transformed from his former skill,
But added flame vnto his former fire,
His former paine, and wypt away his toylsoms weat.
Yet she still followed her former stile,
Who maistring them, renewd his former heat;
And great disparagment makes to his former might.
Yet such, as were through former flight preseru'd,
Let them returned be vnto their former state.
All were he wearie of his former paine,
Tho gan she to renew her former smart,
Into her former fit; for why, no powre
Ere they to former rule restor'd shalbee,
At last the fury past, to former hew
But Britomart kept on her former course,
Her former sorrow into suddein wrath,
To sorrow huge she turnd her former play,
Yet former feare of being fowly shent,
Where wicked ghosts do waile their former sin.
By this her Damzels, which the former chace
Being through former bathing mollifide,
Her former loue, and stedfast loialty,
Euer alike, as if her former dred
Thence backe returning to the former land,
His former griefe with furie fresh reuiued,
To make another like the former Dame,
And soone forgot his former sickly paine;
His former suit, and from them fled apace;
And leaue me to my former languishing;
Much fairer, then the former, was that roome,
Restore vnto her health, and former state;
Which who so list looke backe to former ages,
So did they all their former strife accord;
That now had chang'd her former wonted hew:
He was full wo, and gan his former griefe renew.
That through the bruses of his former fight,
Now with recounting of like former breaches
In whom he liu'd a new, of former life depriued.
Now made forget their former cruell mood,
And forth vpon his former voiage fared,
New matter added to his former fire;
And fayned still her former angry mood,
He by his former combate would not bide,
Yet trembling euery ioynt through former feare;
And him restore to former grace againe.
And him receiu'd againe to former fauours state.
He though affide vnto a former loue,
He would her shortly leaue, and former loue forget.
Which I, that was not bent to former loue,
My former hardnesse first I faire excusd;
And vnto former liberty restore.
Resolued to pursue his former quest;
So all afresh gan former fight renew.
For I thereby my former loue haue lost,
Then all his former parts did earst appere.
Marinells former wound is heald,
But then he fear'd his mothers former charge
That that same former fatall wound of his
Ne former strength returne so suddenly,
Which done, vnto his former iourney he retourned.
But he ere long the former fiftie bet;
And former liuelod fayle, she left me quight,
And gan renew her former cruelnesse:
That all his former praise doth fowly spill.
Gan her addresse vnto her former way.
That after those two former rode apace,
As they were follow'd of their former feare.
They quite forgot, and scornd all former law;
Being returned to his former hew:
To th'hearing of that former cause in hand,
His former fancies ruth he gan repent,
Her name was Belgï¿½, who in former age
To graunt him that aduenture for his former feat.
And to his former iourney him addrest,
They turne afresh, and oft renew their former threat.
That all my former praise hath blemisht sore;
My former shield I may resume againe:
But to release his former foule condition.
For recompence of all their former wrong:
He now againe is on his former way,
And Calidore forth passed to his former payne.
Gan freshly him addresse vnto his former way.
Of former daies mishap, his sorrowes wicked sourse.
His former malice to some new assay,
Till that at length nigh tyrd with former chace,
That they to pitty turnd their former rage,
Yet did her face and former parts professe
The Prince according to the former token,
As one that had no life him left through former feare.
Who notwithstanding that in former fight
Yet nought abating of his former spight,
Of him, for all his former follies meed,
Wearie of trauell in his former fight,
But most the former villaine, which did lead
So fresh the image of her former dread,
His former quest, so full of toile and paine;
Who scarcely yet from former feare exempted,
Would not for ought be drawne to former drede,
Then all the stormes of fortunes former yre
Knowing his fatall hand by former feare;
Tho rearing vp his former feete on hight,
More then my former writs, all were they clearest
And on the helmet smote him formerlie,
Formerly grounded, and fast setteled
And her faire lockes, which formerly were bownd
A thousand charmes he formerly did proue;
Whom formerly he had in battell wonne,
That precious iuell, which she formerly
Which lawlesse men had formerly fordonne.
Vnlesse that with his Lord he formerly did fight.
As many formes and shapes in seeming wise,
For by those vgly formes weren pourtrayd,
The house of goodly formes and faire aspects,
And vncouth formes, which none yet euer knew,
To change her hew, and sundry formes to don,
For formes are variable and decay,
For him the Father of all formes they call;
A thousand monstrous formes therein were made,
For loue in thousand monstrous formes doth oft appeare.
What euer formes ye list thereto apply,
The vtmost rowme, and past the formest dore,
Thereat that formost matrone me did blame,
But that swift Talus did the formost win;
Still slew the formost, that came first to hand,
By euery fornace many feends did bide,
And hundred fornaces all burning bright;
One day, as he forpassed by the plaine
He was so wasted and forpined quight,
And witnesse forth aright in forrain land,
Attyr'd in forraine armes and straunge aray:
Or being carried farre from forraine lands.
Are not all places full of forraine powres?
A band of Britons ryding on forray
But to forray the land, or scoure the deepe.
After a late forray, and slept full sound,
For dead now was their foe, which them forrayed late.
Of neighbour Scots, and forrein Scatterlings,
Against their forrein foe, that comes from farre,
The powre of forrein Paynims, which inuade thy land.
Which Vther with those forrein Pagans held,
Farre thence from forrein land, where they did dwell,
Her to defend against all forrein foes,
Into some forrein land, where as no need
